title: Rent Control Supply Destruction
context: Cities facing housing affordability crises implement rent control to protect tenants from rising costs. The policy delivers immediate relief to current renters. But it simultaneously destroys the economic incentive to build new housing, maintain existing units, or enter the rental market. Over 5-15 years, the housing supply shrinks, quality deteriorates, and the affordability crisis deepens for everyone not already locked into a controlled unit.
hypothesis: Rent control makes housing more affordable and protects tenants from displacement.

effects.label: Current tenants get immediate rent relief

children.label: Tenants stay in units longer — reduced mobility
Misallocation: empty nesters in 3-bedrooms, families in studios
Tenants afraid to move because they'll lose controlled rate
Units eventually become uninhabitable and exit the market

effects.label: New construction declines
effects.impact: 15-20% reduction in new rental housing starts

children.label: Developers build condos or commercial instead of rentals
Market-rate units become even more expensive due to scarcity
Landlords screen tenants more aggressively — discrimination increases

dontIf: Your city already has a housing supply shortage
You're implementing rent control as a substitute for building more housing
ifYouMust: Pair rent control with aggressive supply-side incentives (zoning reform, tax breaks for builders)
Include vacancy decontrol so units reset to market rate between tenants
Exempt new construction for 15-20 years to avoid chilling development
Fund maintenance requirements with landlord tax credits

alternatives.name: Upzoning and density bonuses
alternatives.note: Increase supply by allowing more housing to be built — addresses root cause

alternatives.name: Housing vouchers
alternatives.note: Subsidize tenants directly without distorting the rental market

alternatives.name: Community land trusts
alternatives.note: Remove land from speculative market while maintaining housing quality

sources.title: Stanford: The Effects of Rent Control Expansion on Tenants, Landlords, and Inequality
sources.note: San Francisco rent control reduced rental supply by 15% and increased rents for non-controlled units by 5.1%

sources.title: Brookings: What Does Economic Evidence Tell Us About Rent Control?
sources.note: Comprehensive review finding rent control reduces supply and misallocates housing

sources.title: IGM Forum: Rent Control Survey of Economists
sources.note: 81% of economists agree rent control reduces housing quantity and quality over time

sources.title: NBER: Housing Market Spillovers from Rent Control
sources.note: Rent control causes landlords to convert rentals to condos, reducing rental supply

falsifiability: Cities with rent control show equal or greater rental housing supply growth compared to similar cities without it over 10+ years
Housing quality in rent-controlled units remains comparable to market-rate units over 15+ years
Market-rate rents in cities with rent control grow at the same rate as comparable cities without it

seo.description: Rent control saves current tenants 15-25% but reduces housing supply by 15% over a decade and pushes market-rate rents higher. 81% of economists agree it backfires.
